Coconut- and pineapple-flavoured milkshake IPA, thanks Sérgio (the brewer of Totenhopfen in Luxemburg) for sharing.  Papery lacing, off-white, mousy, stable head on a misty apricot blonde beer with ochre-ish hue.  Aroma very strongly coconut-forward (coconut milk), some pineapple jam but much less outspoken than the coconut, blood orange, vanilla custard, dough, milk powder, powder sugar, ground hazelnuts somewhere, nougat.  Sweet and creamy onset with a citric twist to it, pineapple indeed in a candied- or jam-like way, hints of mango, lychee and blood orange, fizzy carb (quite sharpish for the style but not to a bothersome degree); full, supple, soft body with lactose creaminess – and sweetness on top of the malt sweetness.  Becomes highly aromatized very quickly, by tropical hops (mango) but even more so by vanilla (love it) and most predominantly so by the coconut; some light and late powdery bitterness lingers, but creamy lactose sweetness and coconut last for a long(er) time.  This is about as decadent as it gets in the vast IPA world, but I seem to have a thing for milkshake IPAs if they are well done, and that certainly is the case here.  This kind of desserty sweetness was unthinkable in any IPA as little as ten years ago, but here we are – products like this are bound to attract a large audience, and frankly I would like to see an adventurous Belgian brewery tackle this offspring of the ubiquitous New England IPA (the only one who has successfully done a milkshake IPA in this country so far that I know of, is Totem, so hopefully others will follow).

J'avais une certaine appréhension en decapsulant cette Westmalle double tant la triple est pour moi un graal absolu et tant le style des doubles est un style compliqué. J'aurais donc mis un temps certain avant de franchir le pas. Et oui, donc le style n'est pas évident pour aboutir à des bières exceptionnelles, mais cette Westmalle double est très agréable, sous couvert d'un excellent équilibre et pêche finalement d'un manque de pep's et de caractère que l'on retrouve sur la triple. Quelque peu douceâtre, cette double a du mal nous amener vers des envolées lyriques. On u retrouve cependant tout le savoir-faire des bières trappistes. Belle prestation en verre avec un brun soutenu et une mousse brune crémeuse et généreuse. Le nez est doux, sur le chocolat, la noisette, le caramel, la banane avec heureusement quelques épices (coriandre et girofle) qui viennent réveiller le tout. L'attaque présente une fraiche amertume sur une base douce reprenant le cocktail découvert au nez. Mes arômes y sont cependant pleins. La deuxième bouche est dans la lignée avec un alcool à 7% d'une bonne efficacité, même si un 8% pourrait ne pas faire de mal pour donner un peu plus de pep's. L’arrière-bouche, sur une amertume fraîche est un brin astringent. Belle corpulence, doublée d'une bonne longueur avec un final tout en douceur. Un manque d'envolée lyrique qui nous empêche une parfaite élévation spirituelle, mais une double bien faîte et agréable.

Northern English double NEIPA, from tap at Bar Beenhouwer in Ghent.  Egg-white, membrane-lacing, creamy, thin, irregularly edged and eventually all but dissolving head, cloudy yolk-yellow robe with pale orangey tinge – the whole thing quickly looks like a glass of freshly squeezed orange juice.  Aroma of mandarin, mango, ripe pineapple juice, sweetish with a sourish edge, fizzily carbonated; soft doughy malt body, completely drenched in dank, very sultry, tropical hoppiness, sweet-citrusy and a bit mango-like, but with a powdery, weedy bitterishness in the end as well – though eventually more bitterness comes from wodka-like alcohol, emphasizing an overall effect I can only describe as Screwdriver-like.  Typical new wave double NEIPA, mimicking orange juice with wodka poured in.

Chardonnay barrel aged, light ‘session’ sour, from a waxed bomber bought at Geers in Oostakker near Ghent.  Thin and loose, mousy, bubbly, snow white head disappearing completely in the end, misty pale yellowish straw blonde robe with lime-greenish tinge.  Aroma of diluted lemon juice, indeed Chardonnay wine and white grape skin, green apple, soap, buttermilk, lime, dough, fried ‘courgette’, pumice.  Restrained fruity esters (green banana, green apple) in a softly lactic-sour, minerally environment, softly carbonated, with a soapy wheatiness and cereally main maltiness in the middle; drying lactic sourness in the end too, but remaining fairly gentle, while wood tannins from the barrels remain all but absent.  Still, the finish does bring a notable white wine flavour, which in the end adds some complexity to the whole; lots of chalkiness lingering too, though.  Soft sour ‘afterburn’.  Fruity, not lacking in complexity but it does lack in the promised Brett and wood effects, even if the Chardonnay is certainly there.  Feels like a Berliner Weisse with a dash of Chardonnay thrown in, and that is probably not that far removed from the truth.  Interesting, but too expensive for what it is and delivering only half of what it promises.
Tap. Hazy yellow color with white head. Aroma is exotic fruits, mineraly, dank, fresh. Taste is the same. Oily mouthfeel with soft carbonation. Quite nice!
Tap. Hazy orange color with white head. Aroma is gummybears, a bit piney, petrol. Taste is the same. Silky mouthfeel with sparkly carbonation. Quite amazing for this ABV.
Tap. Unclear golden color with white head. Aroma is cheesy, gummybears, white sugar. Taste is the same. Oily mouthfeel with low carbonation. Not great unfortunately.
Tap. Hazy golden color with white head. Aroma is piney, pale malts, sticky hops, resinous, peach. Taste is the same. Thick oily mouthfeel with low carbonation. Quite sweet.
Tap. Hazy golden color with white head. Aroma is herbal, juniper, gin indeed. Taste is herbal, juniper, all the botanicals. Oily mouthfeel with low carbonation. Well-made!

Draft. A dark brown beer with a lazing brown head. The aroma has notes of chocolate, coffee, and roasted malt. The flavor is sweet with notes of chocolate, roasted malt, and coffee, leading to a bitter finish.

Poured from a bottle into a tulip glass.  Rich, chocolate and coffee aroma.  Almost black when poured, with a beige head that dissipates quickly to form a collar.  Medium body and carbonation.  Chocolate comes through in the taste with a good amount of bitterness to finish.  Smashing brew.

Perfectly clear deep copper and almost amber coloured body with a decent two centimetre tall, very soapy white head that fades to literally nothing on top - just like a soda - pretty bad, actually. Aroma of wheat, bubble gum, oranges, a dash of curacao and some softer earthy and malt components that make this okay, but not great, in the nose, at least. Light to Medium-bodied; Strong wheatie and yeastie flavours dominate with a large cardboardie and funky flavour at first that shows some light orange and curacao notes, a dash of citrus, a little grain and some more assertive sugars that show caster sugar notes and a slight touch of fruit-based sugars. Aftertaste shows the more dry and slighlty softer flavours from the malt with a dry and orangey finish that has some light sweetness, but mostly the stale or funky wheat-based malt profile that doesn't have any complexities or depth from the yeast strain at all. Overall, a pretty poor beer overall, and definitely not a respectable FILTERED wheat beer as this definiteliy shows as a Wheat Ale, and even then, not a good one with bad/old wheat notes, no real yeast depth and no other complexities from other notes - just the wheat shows through, in a not-so-good way. I sampled this twelve ounce can, purchased from Knightly Spirits in Orlando (Orange Blossom Trail), Florida on 28-December-2017 for US$2,29 sampled just over two years later at home in Washington on 04-February-2020.
Draft. A hazy red beer with a thin beige head. The aroma has notes of berries and malt. The flavor is very sweet with notes of berries, citrus fruits, and malt, leading to a dry finish.
Very dark mahogany, generous loose foam and berries on the nose. Rich and full in the mouth, then drying with a bitter, slightly acrid note coming in.

Beer Names: Colchester Old King Coel London Porter
Reviews: Deep mahogany with a loose head. Treacle toffee and on the nose. Rich and roasty-sweet, warming, though a bit cloying and burnt on the finish.

KØLF 291119. Black color with a brown head. Aroma is roasted malt, coffee, chocolate. Flavor is roasted malt, coffee, chocolate, alcohol, sugar, caramel, lactose, salt, licorice, tonka beans. Very nice beer.
Cask at GBBF Winter 2020, red-brown and lightly hazy, a fine crema and a sweetish nose with a winey hint. Sweet with an oddly astringent finish.

Aroma : Roasted chocolate malt, light coconut touch and a hint of burnt wood.  Taste : Coconut is not especially evident in the taste; it gets lost in the lovely roasted chocolate malt. Nice bitter sweet balance; a decent porter (Florida tour Nov 2018)
Deep red, a touch of fruit and sweet coffee on the nose. Sweet and burnt, a bit cloying.

750-ml bottle from mousetrap. gushed but expectedly so didn't lose much, good smooth-on-top beautiful-from-the-side loudly fizzy head, arcs of lace, beautiful hazy reddish syrup color, wild malty nose, full body, berry, yogurt, tart, perfectly balanced, bready finish. rating #1!

On tap at 33 Exp, pours black with a small light brown head. Aroma reveals hearty oats upfront, with gentle roast and a nice earthiness. Flavour is very hearty, with lots of hearty oats, a touch of coffee, and medium roast. Rounded and deep, with good drinkability. How I want my oatmeal stout to be. What the hell are you on about, Dean? Very good.

On tap at 33 Exp, pours a hazy dull blonde with a small whit shear. Aroma reveals lots of coriander, gentle salt, and citric notes. Flavour reveals plenty of coriander and yogurty lacto upfront, with plenty of citrus and moderate salt. Quite citric and spicy on the finish. Decently made.

On tap at 33 Exp, pours a hazy dark red with a small beige head. Aroma is full of jammy berries, moderate pith, and some lacto. Flavour is very fruity, with mixed red berries, lots of lacto, and a hint of sweetness. Quite pithy and tart. Fun beer, but not very complex.

On tap at 33 Exp, pours a clear copper golden with a small beige head. Aroma brings out bitter piney hops and crisp biscuity malt, in west good coast fashion. Flavour is quite bitter, with plenty of bright, biting piney hops, a little grass, and crisp biscuity malt. Nice to image a proper west coast IPA amidst all the hazy these days. Piney and crisp. Nothing mind-blowing, just very well-made.

On tap at 33 Exp, pours a clear pale golden blonde with a small white head. Aroma brings out a very peppery spiced character with little else discernible. Flavour is along the same lines, with grassy notes, a herbal character, and crisp biscuity malt. Herbal and spicy. It’s alright.

On tap at 33 Exp, pours a cloudy dull golden with a small white head. Aroma is full of lacto upfront, with everything else taking a backseat - there’s some floral hops in there, but they’re drowned out by the yogurt. Flavour is more balanced between the lacto and hops, with harsh floral hops and lots of yogurt. Not overly well-integrated, but it’s a fun one.

On tap at 33 Exp, pours a hazy bronze with a small white head. Aroma reveals earthy coffee upfront, with little of the base beer discernible. Flavour is along the same lines, with earthy coffee and a bready malt base. The coffee is nice, albeit very simple. Okay beer.

On tap at 33 Exp, pours a clear copper with a small white head. Aroma brings out sweet candied sugar and estery notes. Flavour is estery and sweet, with a pretty chaotic profile of cotton candy, booze, and out-of-control esters. Not properly brewed. Difficult to drink.

On tap in the brewpub as "Canary Cross Amber". Aroma : light caramel & cereal malts, hint of indistinct red fruit hop.  Taste : Specific flavours don't really come through, but has a light sweet malt feel nicely balanced by a light bittering, not horrible just a tad boring (Florida tour Nov 2018)

On tap at 33 Exp, pours a clear yellowish blonde with a small white head. Aroma brings out dank hops, with almost a sourness to it - lots of weed. Flavour is quite dank and vibrant, with lots of citrus hops, earthy notes, dankness, and crisp dry biscuity malt. Dank, dry and vibrant. Very good.

On tap at 33 Exp, pours a cloudy golden orange with a small white head. Aroma is rather dusty, with earthy hops, sawdust, and cereal malt. Flavour is less vibrant than hoped for a mosaic IPA, with earthy hops, bready malt, and some gentle tropical fruits. Again, not as bright as hoped for. Decent but could be better dialled in.

On tap at 33 Exp, pours a hazy golden blonde with a small white head. Aroma brings out an earthy hop character, with some onion, and some juicy fruit pith. Flavour is more or less the same, with herbal and piney hops, earthy notes, and onion. Not as vibrant as the Sabro I just had, but the clarity is solid. Good stuff

On tap at 33 Exp, pours a cloudy golden with a small white head. Aroma brings out fresh piney hops, some resins, and tropical pithy fruits. Flavour has great clarity, with bright tropical fruits, lots of pithy hops, and some sticky resins. So juicy and with great clarity. Excellent.

Beer Names: Firestone Walker Luponic Distortion Revolution No. 014
Reviews: Can. Clear gold with moderate whitehead. Taste crisp mouthfeel, white grape, hint of grapefruit and orange. Moderate bitterness and medium-light sweetness. Clean dry finish.

Beer Names: Buckledown Barrel Aged Significant - Cacao Nibs & Chocolate
Reviews: 12-oz can from binnys Lincoln Park. huge multi-bubbled foamy head, huge chocolate nose, creamy medium body, chocolate milk, boozy, sweet, roasty finish. rating #1!

Hazy light amber appearance with a beige head. Aroma of toasted malt, bread, fruity esters, mild herbs and light banana. Similar flavor, malty and yeasty sweetness with mild fruit and a light spicy bitterness. Medium body with a soft feel and smooth finish.

Bottled, 330ml from the Thornbridge Brewery Shop, Bakewell, Derbys. Gold to amber with white head. This has quite an assertive resinous bitterness from the off, hoppy, sharp in character. Dry grapefruit flavours, lemon rind, grass, pine needles. Very pleasant.
Light caramel & corn malt, hint of lemon citrus hopLight sweet caramel malt, grain/cereal, and some citrus note. Light and refreshing but nothing special

Poured from a 16 oz can dated January 28, 2020. 
Aroma is fairly hop forward with light cracker malt notes and a hint of alcohol spice. Tropical fruit, citrus and light resin notes. Mango, passion fruit, tangerine and orange notes. 
Pours a fairly clear, golden orange with a large, frothy, pillowy, white head that recedes slowly to a small film that lingers on the edges. Moderately high lacing and faint legs. 
Flavor is slightly sweet with medium light cracker malt notes and a hint of caramel. Strong bitterness with faint alcohol notes. Moderatel hop notes of grapefruit, resin, orange and mango. 
Mouthfeel is medium bodied with medium carbonation. Low astringency and low alcohol warmth. 
Overall, a decent West Coast style IPA. Solid bitterness with decent hop notes and a bit of a background character.
Aroma : Lightly toasted caramel malt, grassy hop.  Taste : As nose, not horrible; just boring !

Can from Joe’s enjoyed after returning from Flint.  Pours a light gold color with a white head. Big aroma of lemony citrus plus sweetness. The flavor is almost like pineapple juice with light pithy bitterness. Kind of an overall brut streak too. Okay.

Tap at Belmont Station. Colour..ruby red with no head. Nose...essence of cherry compote,  kirschwasser and vanilla cream with hints of maraschino juice. Palate...a quick assault of tart cherry tang and then waves of sweet cherry purée dance across the palate. The gleek fest begins at the mid palate and is highly pronounced at the back with plenty of acetic goodness. The finish is laced with vanilla notes and is also long, tart and bittersweet.

Poured from a 16 oz can dated January 28, 2020. 
Aroma is very hop forward and fruity with lots of mango, passion fruit, mango, lychee and some over ripe fruit. Light dank, resin notes. Light cracker malt notes and a hint of alcohol. 
Pours a moderately hazy, golden orange with a medium large, thick, fluffy, white head that recedes slowly to a small film that lingers on the edges. Moderately high lacing and no legs. 
Flavor has a light sweetness with moderate cracker malt notes and a hint of biscuit. Moderate bitterness with fairly high hop notes. Light alcohol notes. Hop notes are mango, passion fruit, lychee and over ripe fruit with a bit of dank, resin notes. 
Mouthfeel is medium bodied with medium carbonation. Low astringency and low alcohol warmth. 
Overall, a pretty nice, hazy IPA. Solid fruity hop notes and esters.

Bottle from Growler Guys.

One bottle of Blåbeer fifteen years ago and I'm still chasing the high every chance I get. I go in knowing there's absolutely no chance, and I yet I go in anyway. 

Hazy plum pour, relatively abundant head. Marvelous blueberry aroma, some funk, some wood. Bracingly tart at first, but the palate acclimates. Full-bodied. Lots of blueberry character. Almost sweet after a while. Modest but notable wine. A dark chocolate pairing is not bad. Good beer.

Box pour @ home. Pours an opaque dark rich dark cherry red with no head. Nose is loaded with tart cherries and gentle funk. Flavour is unsweetened cherry juice in a pleasant way, tart cherries, and a touch of funk in the background. Medium to light bodied, no carbonation, and a light sweetness with a mild acidity. Lovely stuff, and it keeps me going back for more. Love that I can have this in the fridge for a glass a day sort of thing.

Beer Names: New Heights Nothing Fancy Cream Ale
Reviews: 16oz can c/o BenT. Big, foamy, white head atop a filtered yellow-tan body.  Fast rising carbonation bubbles within.  Smooth, easy, medium bodied.  Doesn't lean into the corn that much, and the filtration keeps it clean.  OK.

Can from Berrmoth, Manchester. Black pour with a light tan head. Butterscotch, burnt caramel, chocolate , toffee aroma.Taste is sweet tobacco, toasted coconut, chocolate, iquorice toffee.Thick sweet boozy finish.

Beer Names: Belching Beaver Dia De Los Deftones
Reviews: From a 16 oz can into a stem glass.  pours gold with small head.  Aroma of a lime soda.  Significant carbonation and mouthfeel.  Flavors of grains, minerals, lime juice, slight sweetener, subtle hops.  Overall light, refreshing, OK for the style if you're looking for something tart and light.

Beer Names: Honky Tonk Bardstown Bourbon Barrel Aged Stout
Reviews: Tallboy, Food City, Maryville, TN. Big, persistent tan head on a very dark pour. Inviting aroma full of cocoa, whiskey and dark, dried fruit. A bit acidic, pruney, peaty, woody and boozy, assertively bitter, faintly astringent, not too sweet, roasty.  Body is on the slightly heavy side, the beer is warming, the carbo retention is good. This is a clean and powerful pint. ABV is apparent, but blends well with the overall brew. Solid.

12 oz. bottle from a six-pack brought back from Raley's in Chico, CA.  The aroma is distinctly SN with a clear airiness and a touch of toasted malt with a very light salty top note.   The smell really reminded me of another SN beer which I tried to figure out and I think it's Flipside or Ruthless Rye.  Beautiful crystal clear golden yellow topped with a very fine-bubbled white head.  Lots of hop bitterness right up front in the taste, but not a heavy, cloying bitterness.   Some earthy and citrus pith in the main taste and a more biting dry leaf bitterness on the tongue.  Really interesting mix of hops here.  This is all balanced by a signature caramel sweetness that really ties the taste together and makes this an easy drinking and refreshing beer.  Medium-bodied and slightly creamy.  Finishes with a lasting tongue coating bitterness and toasted malt aftertaste.  Excellent recipe for an anniversary brew.  Happy 40th, Sierra Nevada!

Beer Names: Bent Paddle Imperial Wilderness Tuxedo - Pineapple & Blackberry
Reviews: The Aromas are tart fruit and cereal. Flavors are similar to nose with balanced mild sweet tart upfront with a little rotten fruit. Decent carbonation in body but the Finish is a little off. .
It's good. No unwanted tastes or flavors that I notice. 15 pack for $14.50 before tax.

12 oz can.  Pours golden with some fine particles, but otherwise clear, and a white head.  Aroma is light, but what's there is still distinctively of Centennial hops (floral, herbal, grapefruit) as in Two Hearted.  Flavor light as well, of course, but again herbal and floral hops with a bit of grapefruit, a bit of biscuit.  Also has the right amount of bitterness for the strength.  This is quite good given how light it has to be, but that lightness prevents me from enjoying it enough to give it a higher score.

473ml can. Pours a cloudy orange-yellow with a thin, fizzy, short lived, white head that leaves spotty lacing.  Sweet aroma of caramel malt, lemon, oak and Brett. Sweet fruity flavour of caramel malt, green apple, pear, lemon, Brett and oak in a dry, sour Lacto finish. Medium body with a sticky texture and average carbonation. Enjoyable and well made.

Bottle. Pours opaque black with a creamy medium brown head that dissipates leaving good residual and lacing. Aroma is strong espresso, mocha notes, light vanilla. Flavor is medium sweet, medium bitter, really heavy espresso. Full body, creamy mouthfeel, lingering heat. Very nice coffee stout, but the bourbon barreling is lost in the shuffle here, unfortunately.

Pours thick black with a thin tan head.  Aroma is cocoa, lactose and roast.  Taste is rich chocolate and lactose, moving to roast and some earthy notes.  Finish is chocolate milk and roast.  Tasty stout.

Pours cola black with a small off white fizz.  Aroma is chocolate and roasted malts.  Taste is slightly thin but considering it is a session, it's acceptable.  Roasted malts and some chocolate with some light coffee.
Can, courtesy of Ben. Pours a bright hazy orange. Tangerine, floral, lemon, blueberry, little hop spice. Good body. Good.

16 oz can pours a clear pale golden with small fizzy head that vanishes in a few seconds without leaving any lacing.  Aroma may have passionfruit and hemp seed, but reminds me more of Jolly Ranchers.  Taste is sweet, more like a soda than a malt liquor, with hardly any booziness.  Body is medium with lively carbonation.  It fails as a beer but succeeds as something to get you buzzed quickly if you don't like the taste of normal beer.

Can from The Davis Beer Shoppe. Pours dark brn/blk with a huge foamy Guinness tan head. Pours like Guinness! Nitro like. Aroma of dark chocolate and somewhat toasty malt escapes the foam. Med plus body. Flavor is slightly burnt malt, chocolate and hints of darker fruits. I think it's pretty dry. Bitter arguably comes from the malt. It's a very nice drink.

Cocoa-colored with tan head that doesn't stick around.  Carbonation produces foamy head which lingers.  Vinous, lactic aroma.  Extremely sour to the point it's difficult to taste anything.  Very dry finish with vinous aftertaste.  Feel like I need to drink something between sips to rehydrate my mouth.  I want to like this given the other positive reviews, but I'm just not seeing it.  Overall: too sour, too little going on, and I'm not convinced the cherries or poppies are doing anything.

Draft at Cugino’s, served in a smaller glass. Pours a hazy gold with a small white head that settles into a thin ring and small island of film. Notes of tangerine, florals, vanilla, sweet and bready malts, stone fruits, herbs, and resin. Faint boozy warmth. Medium-bodied, with modest carbonation and a citrusy, sweet, bitter mouthfeel in pretty good balance. Nice entry into the Fallen Flag series.
Pours a deep, oily black, with mid-sized, tan head. Aroma of roasted grain, some nuts, chocolate. Flavor follows, with a light sweetness. This is pretty good.

Draft at Cugino’s, served in a smaller glass. Pours a deep, semi-cloudy brownish amber with a small off-white head that settles into a ring and island of film, leaving plenty of ropes of lace in the glass. Notes of toasty and slightly smoky malts, chocolate, tobacco, earth, brown sugar, and tea. Light-bodied, with modest carbonation and a malty, toasty, semi-sweet mouthfeel. Nice.
Dark brown body with amber highlights and no head, roasty malty nose, flavor is pretty sweet, lots of residual sugars, Dark roasted malts, finish is all black malt, well bittered

12 oz. tall can. Pours a pale ale color, with a bit of pink peeping in. Fizzy sparkling wine head but a bit more persistent. Does have a chardonnay nose to it. The taste does bring up ideas of rosé wine, and the sparkle doesn't hurt at all. The dry red wine taste continues to the red; not overly "winey," but well matched to the beer background.

Beer Names: Carton Turn Up The Hook Strata Remix
Reviews: 16 ounce can. Hazy orange gold pour. Small creamy beige head. Dank citrus hop nose. Flavor follows nose, with lots of sharp citrus character. Notes of lemon, lime, grapefruit, passion fruit and spring onions. Warming alcohol in middle. Dank resiny pine finish is long and bitter.

Draft at Cugino’s, served in a smaller glass. Pours a clear gold with a finger of white head that settles into a thick ring and thin half film. Notes of wheat, dough, clove, banana, lemon, and some residual sweetness. Light-medium bodied, with moderate carbonation and a sweet, malty mouthfeel. True to style.
Can from H-E-B. Bright orange. Strong citrus and tropical aroma. Orange, tangy, very mildly bitter finish.

Beer Names: Cigar City Caffè Americano Double Stout (Bourbon Barrel-Aged)
Reviews: Bottle shared at bowling opaque black with moderate tan head. Nose bourbon, coffee, mineral chocolate. Taste coffee, molasses, almost maple, mineral chocolate. Light bourbon.
Pours clear yellow with a thin white head. Aroma of grassy malt. Taste has fantastic rich malt, grassy hops that persist on the tongue. Palate has smoked malt on the tongue and nose. Je ne seis quoi.

Sort of a pale amber colour, bright, but lifeless, with no head. I have to say I agree with Dean here - I've known people who drink only ghetto white and this comes across that way. Like a ghetto white mixed with some flabby malts. On the palate, I like it better. It still has a bit of that cheap white character, but that vinous note is a bit snappier, as the acidity comes in a touch. Still some biscuity unfermented malt that leaves a bit too much of an impact, but it's better on the palate.

500 ml bottle from the brewery (as Everything Goes Away with Southern Star & Amarillo).  Pours a very murky peach colour with moderate-sized off-white head.  Aroma is dank pine, orange, other citrus fruit and some green hop character.  Flavour has big dank, green character with lots of pine, orange and lychee.  Fairly bitter in the finish.  Medium-full body.  Nice.
16 oz can from Brewers Haven.  Light haze on the pour, fluffy head fades. Fruity aroma, heavy on the tropical. Taste also is tropical, with a heavy dryness. Sweet and not that bitter
Pours hazy, light head with a tropical aroma. Smooth from start to finish. Not too bitter. Just right. Cheers!!!

12oz can at home via WY, thanks iphonephan!  Clear golden amber with a medium white head with good retention and lacing.  Lemon and orange citrus, piney and grassy hops, some bready malt.  Medium carb and body with a smooth texture and a lingering, bittering finish.  Excellent.

Cask pour at Side Project Cellar. Pours a cloudy brick red with a cascading khaki head that settles into a ring and island of film. Notes of balsamic, some acidity, cherries, brown sugar, oak, raspberries, and funk. Light-medium bodied, with moderate carbonation and an acidic, sharp mouthfeel. Has some pucker. Very good overall.

500 ml bottle from Tavour. Nose is sweet honey, tart apples, and hints of bubblegum. Murky yellow gold with a small white head. Flavor is moderately sweet with a hint of tartness. Flavor is sweet honey, slightly tart apples, and a possibly imaginary hint of cinnamon.
Vintage bottle shared by alexsdad06 pour opaque black with thin tan head. Nose light bourbon and molasses, light caramel, light earthy. Taste raisin, molasses, light barrel, molasses.
Wow. Great oatmeal stout. Strong roasted malt aroma. Perfect dark and foreboding color. Flavors were full with a silky body.

Beer Names: Odd Side Ales Hipster Brunch Stout
Reviews: Bottle from Total Wine. Black with a big, thick lacing tan head. Aroma of roasted malt, cocoa, rye, wood, coffee, and vanilla. Rich, roasty, sweet and a little boozy. Full bodied and smooth. Very nice.
bomber from 2018; so aged a little - good gingerbread aroma. dark pour of course; not much gingerbread in flavor but some holiday spices in flavor.  med. palate.  base stout is average.  ok brew
Average dark lager. Not as bold as it could be. Slight burnt malt flavor with a low hoppiness. Just OK.
Decent but was hoping for better. Dark malt mixed with pepper but muted. Needs some tweaking.

Beer Names: By The Horns Blood Orange IPA
Reviews: Great aroma and flavor of citrus bitterness with blood orange standing out. Medium weight and dark orange color.
Solid beer that many don't get right. Malty up front with a wheat bread flavor mixed with dark candy. Nice color and feel.

Draft at Cugino’s, served in a smaller glass. Pours a cloudy pink color with a small white head that settles into a ring. Notes of passionfruit, raspberry, guava, lime, floral zest, wheat, salt, and coriander. Medium-bodied, with modest carbonation and a fruity, tart, zesty mouthfeel. Really tasty.

Beer Names: Collective Arts Collective Project: IPA Project #12
Reviews: Can. Opaque and yellowish. On the nose, this is fairly assertive with lots of grapefruit and gooseberry stuff. The Sauvin is pretty big here. On the palate, it has quite a light body, and then big, bright Nelson accents, lots of subtropical bright fruits. Low bitterness. Hits the hazy style in a really nice way.
Better than average hefeweizen. Wheaty and yeasty with the right amount of spice. Yellow with a big head.

Draft at Cugino’s, served in a smaller glass. Pours a hazy maroon color with a small pink head that settles into a ring. Notes of boysenberry, blackberry, cream, vanilla, wheaty and doughy malts, salt, and coriander. Medium-bodied, with soft carbonation and a fruity, sweet, malty, and barely sweet mouthfeel. Sweeter and wheatier than some others.
12 oz can, poured black with tan head.  Full body.    Chocolate and licorice aroma.  Boozy cocoa and roasted grain taste.  Sweet malt finish.
Solid IPA. Good hoppy and floral aroma. Bitter but not harsh. Balanced with a honey sweetness from the malt.

650 ml bottle from Canada Craft Club.  Pours a cloudy caramel colour with modest-sized cream coloured head.  Aroma is sweetish caramel, grass and gentle toastiness.  Flavour is modestly sweet toffee, some tree fruit, light grass and a hint of toasted grains.  Body verging on medium.  Solid amber.
Average Kolsch beer. Light yellow color. Crisp and clean with cereal malt flavors.

Draft at Cugino’s, served in a smaller glass. Pours a hazy ruby color with a finger of pink head that settles into a thick ring that curves into a thin film while totally lacing the glass. Notes of boysenberry, raspberry, blueberry, cream, vanilla, sweet and doughy malts, salt, and coriander. Medium-bodied, with soft carbonation and a fruity, tart, sweet mouthfeel. Really tasty.
Crisp and light body. Cereal and corn flavor. Mild aroma. Low hops with a pleasant lager yeast finish.

Beer Names: Pedernales Robert Earl Keen River Raft
Reviews: Pretty basic Pilsner. Mild grain aroma. Light golden color and light body.  Sweet grain flavor.

16 oz. can from Cappy's shared with drsordr and Corey. Pours dark brown to black in color with a small plus sized light khaki colored head. The aroma and flavor have roasted malts, dark chocolate, milk chocolate, caramel, coffee, basically a solid sessionable (wink) old school imperial stout.

Bottle
Opened tonight and was unsure of what I’d find. 
Appearance - clear rich copper, iced tea color 
Aroma -rich ripe fruit, prune, dried apricot, dried cherry, ripe apple, licorice 
Taste - ripe stone fruits, caramel, subtle licorice, light notes of leather and earth
Delicious 9 year old beer

Bottle picked up from Biervana, München and consumed at home Attenkirchen, Sunday 2nd February 2020 whilst in the midst of a day of cooking, we've made Cream of Cauliflower Soup, Red Lentil and Tomato Soup, Granola, a large Hungarian Goulash, Roasted a Pork Joint and also making Potatoes and Smoked Garlic. We're listening to Balthazar - Rats. Think is excellent, smoke (lots of) but smooth and easy drinking. Sweet and even a little fish edge also some smoked honey. Glad I got a couple of these, this is great.
Can shared by alexsdad06 pour opaque cola to black with minimal tan head. Nose sweet chocolate, red fruit, coffee. Taste chocolate, coffee, red fruit, light roast. Tasty.

Beer Names: Woodstock Inn Mosaic Papaya Pale Ale
Reviews: 16oz can at home, via FL oddly enough.      Call me crazy, I was expecting this to be hazy from NH, but it’s mostly clear golden bronze with a thin off-white head.  Fruity nose and flavors - papaya, pineapple, sweet mango, but also an odd note of old apricots. Low carb, light body.  Sweet finish, very lightly hopped.  Ok.

Cans from GS brew pub store, neat label. Pours a golden amber with a creamy head. Smooth delicate and fresh - citrus peel and grass and smooth malt and candy citrus/pale fruit. Nice mingling citrus flavors in the finish, kind of like 3-fruit marmalade but with a snappy fresh dryness. What balance. Aroma has a whiff of the freshest mandarin.

Beer Names: Hoof Hearted Everybody Wants Some 3X - Mosaic
Reviews: 16 oz. can from Cappy's shared with drsordr and Corey. Pours a slightly hazy golden color with a small off white head that settles into a thin film. The aroma and flavor have pale malts, some sweetness, smooth, citrus, tropical fruit, melon, light earthy character but not what I would expect from a triple dry hopped Mosaic imperial IPA.

Can from a Lazy Dog. 
Lightly hazy dark golden color with a good sized frothy off white head that persists. Citrus and pine with a fair amount of sweet bread and mineral water.

Can.

Head is initially small, frothy, brown, mostly diminishing.
Body is dark brown to black.

Aroma is moderately malty (roasted grain, cocoa powder), lightly hoppy (herbs).

Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter.
Finish is lightly to moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly to moderately bitter.

Medium body, watery/syrupy texture, lively carbonation.

Kinda sweet and simple, and a little flabby, but not too bad.

Lightly cloudy golden with a fading white head. Lightly briney citrusy limey aroma with some mango and light soursop. Nice gently tart limey and mango salty flavor that’s not too heavy on the salt but has a nice salinic undertone.

Beer Names: Hoof Hearted Everybody Wants Some 3X - Mosaic
Reviews: Can shared by alexsdad06 pour clear gold with moderate white head. Nose macerated fruit, dank, light grass. Taste similar to nose, lots of fruit. Surprisingly no grass or onion.

Can (10/29/19) pour. Appearance is orange-yellow with tons of effervescent sparkle, finger-width foamy white head with decent retention and mildest lacing. Aroma is strong, sweet fruit, spicy. Taste is passionfruit, citrus bite. Mouthfeel is light-to-medium bodied with smooth, thick texture, lively carbonation (biting the tongue), hint of alcohol warmth deep in the esophagus and finish as taste. Overall, strong and enjoyable aroma and flavor but not complex. Hops just out of peak freshness so may be better fresh.

16 oz. can shared by drsordr. Pours a hazy golden color with a medium plus sized off white head. The aroma and flavor have pale malts, lightly toasted, mild sweetness, citrus and earthy hops, grass, some onion character but this is a well put together beer, I am always cautious with 100% Mosaic hopped beers but this was very good.

Can pours a super clear, bright golden color with a big fluffy white head that lingers leaving curtains of lace on glass. Smells of citrus fruit, bread herbs, perfume and pine. Taste of sweet bread, grapefruit, lemon bread, and resin. Light body, super carbonated, soft mouthfeel and a dry finish. Crisp, clean, dry and tasty! Superb!
16 oz can from Joe Canal's, 2/4/20.  Hazy gold, white head, strong lace.  Grapefruit, pineapple, melon, and a little apricot.  Nice juicy flavor, solidly sweet, mildly bitter.  Pretty nice.

Beer Names: Modern Times Fruitlands - Passion Fruit & Guava
Reviews: Draft @ Santiago De Chili.Hazy golden, foamy white head. Lots of acidic mango and passion fruit. Medium body and carbonation.
Draft @ Santiago de Chili. Opaque golden juice, no head. Lots of piney, medium-high bitter mango juice. Medium body and carbonation.

Can from JPs shared with alexsdad06 pour lightly hazy light gold with moderate white head. Nose grassy, resin, light onion, some sweet malt. Taste similar to nose, big grass, light earthy. Some balancing sweetness.

Beer Names: Evil Twin Public Servant: Firefighter Edition
Reviews: 16 oz. can from the Party Source shared with drsordr and Corey. Pours a slightly hazy golden color with a medium plus sized off white head. The aroma and flavor have pale malts, dank tropical fruit and citrus, resin, a hint of cleaner, some bitterness, good but I would pass in the future.
On tap at Library Ale House, Venice Beach CA. Dank tropical fruit aroma. Sweet fluffy peach mango taste with very little bitterness. Actually some bitterness creeps up over time. Solid.

Beer Names: Long Blue Cat Black Arts IPA
Reviews:
Can from a Lazy Dog. 
Dark brown in color with a decent sized tan head that slowly recedes. Roasty earthy with hints of chocolate and earth. Firm bitterness nice flavor.
It's cheap ass hell and it does the job. I get mine at speedway for $1.80 That's including tax!!!

Beer Names: Dominion City Provincial IPA with Cascade and Chinook
Reviews: Can from brewery. Pours hazy mango some head and lots of lacing. Notes are candy, some mango, floral. Medium bitter medium juicy sweet. Full sticky body lively carbonation.

Beer Names: Czig Meister Deep Sea Series: Oasis
Reviews: 16 oz can from Joe Canal's, 2/4/20.  Hazy, rusty, golden-orange.  Decent, somewhat tropical, slightly citrusy aroma and flavor.  Decent mouthfeel as well.  Decent beer.

Beer Names: Spice Trade Little Umbrella - Passion Fruit Mango
Reviews: 12 oz. can purchased at Molly's Spirits in Lakeside, CO. Thanks G-unit! Pours a cloudy apple sauce color with a large white head that exploded all over the counter. Very good retention. Almost no lacing. Tropical fruit aroma.  Strong wheat ale base beer with some undefined tropical fruit flavors. A little sour? This is more of a wheat ale than a fruit beer. Just not working for me. Sounded good,  but a miss.
Lots of funk in this one, a bit of bitter lemon peel, a tiny hint of lactic tartness. Hay flavors, spicy phenols. Excellent.

Beer Names: Evil Twin Public Servant: Firefighter Edition
Reviews: Can shared by alexsdad06 pour avg gold with large white head. Nose dank, over ripe fruit, light floral. Taste similar to nose, more macerated fruit, light dank. Some powder floral late.
Draft at beer culture on 45th. Cloudyish pour. Citrus, hops, honestly maybe the best neipa on history. Balanced like it's walking a tightrope.

Pours barely translucent apricot with a thick and frothy ivory head. Aroma delivers resiny hops, crisp fresh malt, tropical and citrus fruit with a hint of apple. Flavor offers piney and somewhat bitter hops, zesty, tart and sweet fruit - orange, tropical, grapefruit, a whisper of apple - with fresh malt providing the foundation. Texture yields firm body and peppy fizz, and a woody hop finish. Everybody must get Greenstone.
Jet black, nice tan head. Big roast nose. Full bodied, big dry roast, light alcohol heat. Big long bitter finish AWESOME !!

Draft to taster in a flight at BC'S Montgomery and a can shared with drsordr. Pours a clear dark golden color with a small off white head. The aroma and flavor have pale and caramel malts, toasted, earthy hops, grass, herbal tea, any fruit character is mild at best, dry, moderate plus bitterness, good but there is something missing.
Grapefruit, marigold nose. Opaque orange, medium head. Grapefruit, grass. Medium body, easy carbonation.
Golden pour.  Peach and pineapple nose.  Fruity hop taste  salty hop palate
Deep brown, small beige head.. Vague nose.Lightly sweet with toasty notes. More of a brown than porter
16 ounce can.  Pours black with an average brown head.  Aroma of chocolate, coffee, and spice.  Taste is roasted malt, chocolate, Chai, coffee, and spice.  Spicy and different.

4-pack of 16 oz. cans from Marketplace Foods.  $9.99  Pours a relatively clear deep golden color with a nice white head, but the beer appears to be unfiltered as there is some yeast sediment at the bottom of the can.  The aroma is clean with a slight bit of aromatic hops.  The flavor is more of hop oil than of malt, but a pretty good balance.  Overall a nice flavorful beer and not overdone as are so many.
Can shared by alexsdad06 pour dark copper gold with moderate ecru head. Nose dank, grapefruit, pine. Taste moderate bitter up front, pine and grapefruit pith.

16 oz can from Tavour. Pale yellow/golden, tight creamy white head. Gentle citrusy aroma, oranges and grapefruit. Taste is citrusy and juicy with a mellow bitterness that makes this easy to drink. Smooth and creamy
Gold, small white head. Pleasant spicy nose. Palate of spice and pepper, vague fruitiness
12 ounce bottle.  Pours a somewhat hazy gold with a decent white head.  Aroma of citrus and tropical.  Taste is grapefruit, mango, lemon, berries, and malt.  Pretty good.

Beer Names: Streetside / Nine Giant My Friends Over You
Reviews: 16 oz. can shared by Tmoney99 and another with drsordr. Pours a hazy golden color with a medium sized off white head. The aroma and flavor have pale malts, toasted, citrus and earthy hops, tropical fruit, resin, grass, good mouthfeel, very good.
Cloudy amber, off white head. Dank piney citrus nose/palate. Dry & fruity with long strong bitter end. Needs more malt in back

Beer Names: Southern Strain Out to Pasteur (Chardonnay Barrel Aged)
Reviews: It is clear straw with a white head. It has grape elements with lemon, earth, leather, and spice. It is dry.

Beer Names: Streetside / Nine Giant My Friends Over You
Reviews: Can shared by alexsdad06 pour opaque dark tan gold with moderate off white head. Nose big tropical fruit, resin, sweet malt. Taste moderate bitter up front, grass, resin, fruit and light grainy malt.
It is clear yellow with a white head. It has grapefruit, pine, and bread flavors.

Couple of 12 ounce pours at the Westin in Georgetown. Clear and shiny, orange-copper with a thin film of cream. Resin, toast, orange/lemon zest on the nose. Taste has the same, then finishes with drying notes of wood, and lightly peppery citrus pith. Easy drinking with a nice dry slant and smooth, medium carbonation.
It is brown with a light brown head. It is sugary and sweet with toffee, malts, and a slight bit spicy.

Refrigerated 75 cL brown bottle, bottled June 2019 poured into a glass.  Hazy golden with light white head.  Aroma is light lemon, medium/light body, well carbonated, and little lacing.  Taste is mushrooms, light lemon, and salt.
It is very dark brown with a brown head. It has chocolate and roast with some cocoa. It is a bit sweet.

Beer Names: Sugar Creek The Big O Blood Orange IPA
Reviews: It is dark gold with a white head. It has orange flavors with citrus and grapefruit. It is also creamy.

Beer Names: Middle James Cinnamon Sweet Potato Blonde
Reviews: It pours clear yellow with a white head. It has potato flavors with grain, a bit of vanilla, and slight herbal.

8 ounces on tap at The Westin hotel in Georgetown. Deep ebony with a ring of foam. Nose is soy, red wine and bread. Flavors of the same. Smooth low-medium carbonation and medium bodied with a nice balance.

Beer Names: Devil's Logic Castles In the Sky
Reviews: It is cloudy yellow with a white head. It has a bit of dankness to it with grapefruit, citrus, and rind.

Beer Names: The DreamChaser's Just Deal Wit It
Reviews: It is cloudy straw with a white head. There are flavors of coriander, herbs, and a bit of lemon. It is also doughy.

Beer Names: Twenty-Six Acres Basilisk Fang Red Wine Barrel Aged
Reviews: It is very dark brown with a brown head. It has chocolate, roast, cocoa, vanilla, and vinous flavors. It is very smooth.
Very dark brown with a brown head. Chocolate, roast, cocoa, bourbon, and vanilla. It is very smooth.

Very light and pale hazy straw blonde pour. Nice and tight head, two fingers and white. Kind of muted aroma, some soft fruit and citrus. Flavor is nice, understated but plenty of soft citrus and orange, zesty and spicy bitterness. Medium round body.

Draft. Poured clear bright copper color with an average frothy white head that lasted with very good lacing. Moderate to heavy tropical citrus aroma.  Medium to abundant body with a slick texture and soft carbonation. Moderate to heavy juicy bittersweet flavor with a moderate to heavy bittersweet finish of medium to long duration. This beer met my expectations.

Beer Names: Noble Ale Works Big Whig IPA
Reviews: On tap. Pours paler gold good head and lacing. Light piney malty aroma. Balanced malt and hop ipa. Lighter bodied, but still flavorful. Fruity mango, bitter pine and resin hop profile. Enjoyable, well done ipa.

Strawberry or something trying to poke through citrus and sawdust aromas. slightly hazy medium pale yellow with thin white head. flavor is citrus with a thin resin back, tinge of caramel, good edge of bitterness. Full flavor finish.	bought at woodstock new seasons.

Beer Names: Braxton Dark Charge - Rye Whiskey Barrel-Aged - Mandarin
Reviews: Draft. Poured a black color with an average frothy brown head that mostly lasted with very good lacing. Moderate to heavy roasted chocolate, coffee, wood, orange and vanilla aroma. Medium to heavy coffee, vanilla and dark malt flavor with a medium to heavy vanilla sweet and small alcohol bite finish of moderate to long duration. Medium to full body with a smooth texture and flat carbonation. This version is also a standout beer.
It is clear yellow with a white head. It has grapefruit with citrus and rind. It has moderate bitterness.

Overload of coffee, like a cold espresso. Can feel a little alocholic heat on the finish.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Beer Names: Phillips White Out Beaucoup Belgian Blanche
Reviews: Hazy gold, white head. Nose of citrus and spice. Somewhat dry with spicy yeast, coriander and light citrus

This stout poured a deep black colour with a huge, creamy brown head. Beautiful lacing. Scents include light coffee, nuts, roasted malts and smoke. First swig was bold. Really bold. Heavy roasted flavour with tastes of pure coffee grounds and light smoke. Not very sweet, but those roasted malts are delicious. Finish is pure burnt with that dark roast coffee flavours lingering forever.
It is yellow with a white head. It has some spruce with herbs. It is a bit woody as well.

Beer Names: Deschutes Wowza! Lo-Cal Hazy Pale Ale
Reviews: Cloudy yellow, fast fading white head.. Light piney citrus nose.Fruity palate, medium lasting bitterness. Lacks proper balancing malt

Beer Names: Les Grands Bois Ariane Brown Ale
Reviews: Canette - 473ml. Robe brune, moyennement effervescente et coiffée d'un mince col blanc cassé et mousseux. Arôme malté/houblonné équilibré et agrémenté de nuances sucrées et boisées. En bouche, c'est fidèle à l'arôme. Bonne finale boisée. Pas mal.

Beer Names: Bell's V: Song of the Open Road (Leaves of Grass Series)
Reviews: Bottle - American strong might be the best overall classification for this, but it reads really British in character to me - hazy ruby - rich earthy (maybe some golden promise and marris) sweet malt similar to a scotch ale - moderate spiciness, dark bread, caramelized sugars - moderate bitterness, more American in character, finishes - hearty and warming - very good.

Beer Names: Phillips Black Forest Raspberry Chocolate Ale
Reviews: Pretty chestnut, fluffy tan head.Nice chocolate nose and palate. Light berries in taste.Smooth and quaffable, bit a bit thin

Beer Names: Phillips Icicle Bicycle Lemon Citrus Gose
Reviews: Cloudy amber, head dissipates immediately. Dry salty nose. Quite tart fruity palate. Not really a fan

Beer Names: Brewing Project Mexican Hot Chocolate Imperial Stout
Reviews: 473ml can. Opaque, quasi black colour with small to average, forth yto creamy, half-way lasting, minimally lacing, tan head. Sweet-ish, chocolately dark malty and spicy aroma, notes of dark chocolate, chocolate cake, chocolate sauce, some vanilla, cinnamon, peppery spicy and minimally smoky whiffs of chipotle. Taste is sweet, chocolately dark malty and spicy, notes of cinnamon and vanilla, peppery spicy, minimally smoky notes of chipotle bring that typical effect of increasing, accumulating hotness. Oily to viscous texture, smooth and soft palate, completely hidden alcohol. Exactly what it wants to be (Mexican Hot Chocolate) but not in an Imperial way; spiciness really pushes the envelope without crossing the line to discomfort. Pretty good.

16-ounce can purchased in January 2020 with an ABV of 8.7. Pours hazy yellow-gold with a 1/4" bubbly beige head and residual lacing. Aroma: citrus. Flavor: grapefruit, lemon, orange, pineapple, mango, pine. Mouthfeel: medium- to full-bodied, a slick to oily finish.

On tap at the Only Cafe.  Pours a clear golden colour with plus-sized white head.  Aroma is citrus and tropical fruits with some sweet maltiness.  Flavour is orange, grapefruit and floral happiness with sweet biscuity maltiness.  Modest bitterness in finish.  Nice.

Fantastic! 

First sip was great. Rest was better. Merle haggard made it even better. 

Most well rounded Vienna lager o have had.

Wish I had a case of this.

Beer Names: Adroit Theory Therapy Sessions (Coconut, Cinnamon, & Pecan)
Reviews:
On tap at Frisco Tap House in Columbia, MD, where it is listed as Adroit Theory Therapy Sessions (795) at 13.5%. 

Opaque, near black with a thin khaki head and good lacing.  

Aroma of cinnamon, coconut, pecan and molasses. 

Taste of licorice, molasses, maple, coconut, pecan and cinnamon. 

Medium body and low/medium carbonation. 

Slob the sweet side for sure, but awfully good.

On tap at the Only Cafe.  Pours a clear burnt orange colour with moderate-sized off-white head.   Aroma is sharp pine with some citrus, caramel and graininess.  Flavour has lots of pine with some citric character and strong toffee and grainy maltiness.   Not overly boozy.  Medium-full body.  Nice.

This radler poured a cloudy, medium yellow colour with a ultra, fizzy, Bright white, carbonated head. Minimal lacing. Scents include A little bit of peach, must and dough. First swig was quite thin and watery with flavours of light peach, club soda and must. Finish is very light with that minimal peach flavour lingering slightly.
Bottle.  Cloudy amber coloured beer with a strong white head.  The aroma is yeasty and bitter, and the flavour is strongly bitter with yeastiness and a dry finish.  Overall a nice beer.

Gifted to me. Pours nearly clear yellow with almost no head and no lacing, just a ring. Aromas are sweet and citrus-pithy. Flavors follow, only mild bitterness, but I just don't enjoy that pith note. Very smooth, with a surprisingly light mouthfeel. It's okay, but glad I only have one.
HG came baking the biscuits. HG came breaking the barriers. HG broke down the walls and stole all the bread from the bakery.

Bottle from the no-longer-open Brewklopedia, Leicester. Hazy and slightly pinkish yellow with the tiniest ring of white head. Nasal passages are slightly burned by the intense tartness to the aroma. Lemon juice, raspberry, intense mothball funk. Amazing mouth-puckering taste. The sourness fills the whole mouth and longer a long after the sip. More lemon and tart berry in the aftertaste. Medium to heavy carbonation. Special.

Beer Names: Oskar Blues Can O' Bliss Citrus IPA
Reviews:
Can in mix pack
Hazy medium yellow with a white head.
Citrus hop aroma.
The flavor is light tropical fruits with light bitterness.
Chocolate, roasted malt and cocoa, pitch black, very nice, classic roasty stout taste, creamy, smooth, bitter cocoa finish

Tap at tafts ale house in Cincinnati. Cola black brown with medium white head. Roasty nose. Taste is sweet, body is light. Good chocolate and roast character throughout, with almost a brown ale tilt to it. Pretty nice.

From a pint can. Pours a hazy straw with an off white head. Aromas are dank hay. Flay
Flavors are moderately bitter citrus and tropical fruits.

the aroma: hoppy and fruity with hints of bitter orange, key lime, pine, tart berries, resin and spicy herbs...
the taste: fruity and hoppy with notes of sweet and bitter orange, tangerine, red wine, pine needles, berries and spicy grasses...
the aftertaste: sweet, bitter, dry and warming...
summary: very nice...

440ml can from We Brought Beer, Balham.  Clear deep golden.  Aroma is piney and with a certain crispness.  It’s quite malty and quite crisp.  Kind of ticks all the boxes of west coast, but without really ticking them.  This means that it is actually more quintessential than you think. ￼

Obtained at States Street Liquor from Redlands, California for $23.99, Pawpaw is a golden sour ale aged on whole pawpaws brewed by Upland Brewing Company from Bloomington, Indiana. 

The air reveals pawpaws, mango, and peach upon the nose. The appearance is a cloudy yellow that pours a fast dissipating white head. The alcohol content is 7.3%.

Pawpaw provides a creamy banana like feel that follows with a light custard touch. Lemon tarts the take and tones the drink. Mango smooths the mouthfeel and assists with the sweet complexion. Peaches are juicy to the body and deepens the juicy comprehension. A hay-like funk is sensible with the lemon and pawpaw blend along with a soft lactic tinge. Oak offers a woodsy hue to the lemony and creamy pawpaw frame.

Pawpaw is a mesmerizing golden sour ale. Pawpaw, lemon, mango, and peach combination colors the fair sour sensation. The pawpaw comes across like guava except with a custard pinch at the end. The lactic feel is barely noticeable until the beer begins to warm. The sour and tart is easy to experience along with the watery aspect of this libation. I loved each drink and impressed by the pawpaw, lemon, and mango composition.

Cheers. Prost. Drink for the love of beer.

For more beer reviews, visit and like my blog “Drink For the Love of Beer.”

On tap at Bath Brewhouse. Pours opaque orange golden with a white head. Aroma: lactose, stone fruits, citrus. Taste: moderate to heavy sweet, nae bitterness. Lactose & peach. Medium body, creamy mouthfeel, soft carb. Creamy sweet finish. Shite

Can in a trade with tfontana, thanks Tom. 11-20-19 canning. Pushing the limits on hop freshness on this one! But it all works out in the end! Aroma: bold tropical fruit, soft malt. Flavor has strong tropical fruit, mild grassy, and a light malt backbone. Clearly the best beer I ever had from this brewery. Glad they finally stepped up their game!

Bottle from TERMINAL DE CRUCEROS, Puerto Barrios Guatemala.
Clear light yellow with a white head.
Grassy corn aroma.
Not much here flavor-wise.

[33cl can from M&S, Bracknell.] A hazy pale straw coloured pour with a fast fading, soapy looking white head; berry fruit aroma; fruity, biscuity body; with a sharp fruity bitterness and a vegetal finish. Odd.

Beer Names: Tooth & Claw / S43 Chocolate Orange Stout
Reviews: 4/2/2020. Growler sample courtesy of danlo, cheers Ed! Great looking pour, almost black with a nice size light tan coloured head. Aroma of dark chocolate, chocolate orange, light roasted malt, caramel, coffee, dried fruit and a touch of liquorice. Medium sweetness and light to moderate bitterness. Medium body, oily texture, soft carbonation. Very nice.

500ml bottle from local Tesco. Pours black with a tan head. Aroma: malt dominates with hoppy hints. Taste: light to moderate sweet & moderate bitter with the roasted malts overpowering the hops. Hints of dary berry fruits and pine. Medium bodied, soft carbonation. Dry bitter finish. It's OK but the hops need to shine more and roasted malts to be less dominant for it to be a decent BIPA, for me

473ml can. Hazy, bright, orangey golden colour with average, frothy, osteoporosing, moderately lacing, white head. Slightly cautious, juicy, tropical fruity, hoppy aroma, hints of tropical fruit, mango, passion fruit, oaty malty background; resinous and piney notes become laid bare belatedly, a touch of peanut alike, embedded in a mild orange and mandarine cushion. Taste is sweet-ish, wheaty and slightly dry, oaty malty, minimally sugary, unspecific and not overly intense, fruity hoppy, some tropical fruit, some mandarine and orange; again, the initially disguised resinous and piney hoppy core becomes laid bare delayed, only accompanied by diffident mandarine and orange flavours. Minimally mushy texture, smooth and soft palate. Overall too well-behaved, reserved, withdrawn concerning fruity hoppy aspects; with all them fruity flavours evaporated remains a very harmonious and balanced, biscuity pale malty and resinous hoppy DIPA. Somehow like an mediocre Imperial NEIPA in Kernel clothing. So what has to be rated here? I'm indecisive. For now an unmotivated compromise.

330ml Can from Asda, Enniskillen (£1.50):
Light & clear amber a thin, bubbly white lacing that fades fast & leaves a clean, slightly skunky nose with some pale malts, faint grassy notes & a touch of lemon. The taste is bitter & skunky with faint grassy hops & hay coming through alongside bread malts but not much else. The body is light, clean & lightly carbonated but quite sharp at the end too.

On tap at Nepenthe Brewing Co. in Baltimore, MD. 

Murky, tawny gold with an off-white head and excellent lacing.  

Aroma of tropical fruit, oatmeal, honey and fruit I can’t identify. 

Taste of pineapple, tropical fruit, rye bread and kumquat. 

Medium body and medium carbonation.

4/2/2020. Bottle sample courtesy of danlo, cheers Ed! Pours hazy dark amber with a bubbly/frothy off-white head. Aroma of light whiskey, wood, citrus, berries, apple, funky notes and a hint of marzipan. Moderate sweetness and medium tartness. Medium body, oily texture, a bit above average carbonation. Enjoyable.

Pours a clear, golden amber coloration with a small, creamy, stable head. Smells of sweet, doughy malt, coffee cream and vanilla, with just a hint of actual coffee. Taste is very much dominated by sweet, doughy malt, coffee cream and vanilla, with some hazelnut also coming through, as well as just a hint of coffee and white chocolate. Finishes almost sickly sweet, with some coffee cream and vanilla lingering in the aftertaste. Smooth mouthfeel with a medium body and carbonation.

While this does an ok job at imitating a White Russian, it's just way too syrupy sweet and creamy/milky for an enjoyable Imperial Stout, with the vanilla being way overdone and very little coffee coming through. While the mouthfeel is all right, I expected more from a nitro can. Nobody loves the Big Lebowski more than me, but this does not tie it together very well at all, no need to be careful about this beverage. But well, you know, that's just like, my opinion man.

440ml Can from Asda, Enniskillen (£1.50):
Bright amber & hazy with a thin head that's frothy white. The nose is sharp with plenty citrus & dry hops, orange & grapefruit. It's not as strong as expected for the strength but the taste is slightly more pronounced with lots of citrus & orange, grapefruit & bitter pine hops. The alcohol content is masked well & it's fairly easy to drink too, with moderate carbonation & a slightly warming finish.

Beer Names: Saucony Creek Unicorns on a Road Trip
Reviews:
16 oz can from Joe Canal's, 2/4/20.  Canned 12/5/19.  Pours a murky yellowish color, decent off-white head, moderate lace.  Aroma is lemon-lime, grass, pale malts, and a little dough.  Some light citrus notes as well.  Flavor is thin overall, with lemon and pale malts coming through with a mild sweetness and a mild bitterness.  None of the juicy brightness or hop bitterness for that matter that you'd expect from the listed hops, just kind of a thin, watery hoppy blonde ale thing going.  Lively mouthfeel, somewhat dry close.  Feels like either they missed the mark or this is one of those IPAs where if it's more than a month old all the flavor is gone.  Either way, it's mediocre.  
6/3/5/3/11

330ml Can from Asda, Enniskillen (£1.50):
Light, bright amber with a clear body & white, foamy head that holds well. The nose is hoppy with pine & faint citrus but it's definitely subdued. The taste is similarly subdued & slightly off with bitter hop oils, citrus & faint grapefruit. Its a light bodied beer with a smooth, sharp feel but its too light for the most part & a little disappointing.
Can from Emsworth Brewhouse. Cloudy copper colour with medium head, strong citrus aroma, piney hop with a hint of minerals. Nice.

On tap at Nepenthe Brewing Co. in Baltimore, MD. 

Hazy, light yellow with and off-white head and very good lacing.  

Aroma of tangerine, wheat, papaya, mango and other citrus. 

Taste of citrus, tropical fruit and wheat. 

Medium/full body and medium/high carbonation with a foamy mouthfeel.

650ml bottle shared with brother at my place. Thanks for the share Guillaume. Aroma: lots of bourbon, rye too (I know there is no rye), light Cuban cigar, shy roasted malt, lots of chocolate. App: black, thick texture, minimal to no brown head, thick brown lacing. Taste and palate: full body, thick, medium sweetness, roasted bitter finish. Overall: love the nose of this beer. It reminds me of the nose of most of the Alesmith Speedway variants (BASS, BAVSS). The palate is rather sweet but still really easy to drink even if shared with only one person. Great.

330ml Can from Asda, Enniskillen (£1.50):
Caramel amber & a tiny, hazy head that's frothy white head but very thin. It's a sharp, hoppy nose with pine hops & light citrus, herbal touches & floral notes too with some caramel to finish. It's a perfume taste with floral flavours, grassy hops &  pine before sweet malts see things out. The body is medium & dry with a subtle tang at the end; it's an interesting beer but nothing special.

Can, from Beer52. Jet black, fluffy and sustaining beige head and gentle condition. Big roasted barley, liquorice, coffee and a slightly sharp fruity berry note in the nose, quite full in the mouth with a slight creamy sweetness, some blackcurrant fruitiness that becomes slightly tart, hints of bitter coffee and some liquorice notes. Finish has a dry roasted barley bitterness, some sweetness, and a slightly fruity liquorice note lingering.

Pours very dark ruby brown with big foamy head. Aroma is surprisingly close to weissbier with banana and cloves, burnt sugar, wood, dark dried berries. Flavor is sweet and mellow, full body but not too heavy with pleasant texture, hidden but a bit noticeable alcohol, malty and a bit fruity (dark overripe fruits).
Jasnozłociste, klarowne piwo. Piana słaba. Aromat nikły, delikatna nuta kwiatów. W smaku wodniste, cienkie i bez wyrazu. Mocno nasycone, zapychające, goryczki brak.

On tap at Nepenthe Brewing Co. in Baltimore, MD. 

Clear, golden yellow with an off-white head and excellent lacing.  

Aroma of citrus and wet laundry. 

Taste of citrus, pale malt and sweaty socks. 

Medium body and medium/low carbonation.  

This one did not work for me.

Beer Names: Cloudwater / After The Harvest / Oliver's La Deuxième Saison Des Poires
Reviews: 4/2/2020. Bottle sample courtesy of danlo, cheers Ed! Pours hazy pale yellow gold with a short lasting white head. Aroma of citrus, tart perry, dandelion, rubber, gooseberry, lemon puff biscuit and a hint of pineapple. Moderate sweetness and light bitterness/tartness. Moderate body, oily texture, average carbonation. Light tart dry finish. Worked quite nicely.

On tap at Pig & Fiddle, Bath. pours clear mid yellow with a frothy white head. Aroma: pale & sweet malts, grassy hints, light floral. Taste: light to moderate sweet & light bitter, grainy, pinch of lime. Light body, ample carbonation, sweet-ish finish

On tap at Nepenthe Brewing Co. in Baltimore, MD. 

Very hazy, amber gold with an off-white head and excellent lacing.  

Aroma of citrus, tropical fruit and pineapple. 

Taste of mandarin orange, tropical fruit, grapefruit, pineapple and pine. 

Medium/full body and medium/low carbonation. with a luscious mouthfeel.

473ml can drank at home with brother. Thanks for the share. Aroma: lots of onions, burst of fruits, piney. App: milky orange, small to medium white head, great lacing. Taste and palate: full body, yeasty and juicy, fruity a lot, good bitterness finish. Overall: excellent. Love the good balance between the juiciness and bitterness. Really well done. Excellent.

Beer Names: Evil Twin NYC Ever Since I Moved To New York City My Wardrobe Has Shifted To Mostly Black Or Dark Colors
Reviews: Can [email protected], Copenhagen (25/01/2020) - very hazy to opaque orange coloured pour with a white head. Intense big juicy fruity with waves of papaya, mango, grapefruit, pineapple, sweet soft malts, soft pillowy mouthfeel and medium body, bold punchy hoppy finish. Gorgeous!

Very lemony, lots of citrus notes. Enough funk to let you know that this is a real mixed ferm and not another kettle sour, but a lot of lacto notes and it lacks the complexity of some mixed fermentation beers. This is what I'd give to a kettle sour fan who hadn't gotten into real sours yet. Not terrible, but I'm probably not buying it again.

On tap at Nepenthe Brewing Co. in Baltimore, MD. 

Very hazy, leather-yellow with an off-white head and excellent lacing.  

Aroma of orange, lactose, sweet pink grapefruit and pineapple. 

Taste of grapefruit juice, tangerine, pineapple and lactose. 

Medium body and medium carbonation with a soft mouthfeel.

Beer Names: Evil Twin NYC / American Solera Brewers Without Borders
Reviews: Can [email protected], Copenhagen (25/01/2020) -  black with a thin tan head. Dark sweet and roasted malty witn note aof chocolate, caramel, nice coffee roast, bold nutty accents, full body, hazelnut and sweet vanilla coalesce into the dark sweet and roasted malty finish. Lovely stuff.
Dark brown  color pour with an off-white head and light lacing. Malty aroma with nuts and molases in the flavor profile. It has a slightly dry finish.

Beer Names: Evil Twin NYC / Horus Aged Ales Even More Territory
Reviews: Can [email protected], Copenhagen (25/01/2020) - black with a tan covering. Roasted and light sweet dark malty with notes of chocolate, bold coffee roast, burnt brown sugar, full body, nutty chocolate and coffee laden malty finish.

Bottle from rhoihessegold - RB Euro 2020-01 swap - Cheers!
Rocky white head left a froth on a hazy amber coloured still body.
Big juicy aroma of Tropical fruits, pineapple & confectionery.
Medium bodied, slight tingle on the front with a soft cloying back.
Peach, mango, pineapple, Tropical fruits & hoppy tastes with a long tangy finish.
Good one!

Beer Names: Evil Twin NYC Sour Pepper Cherry
Reviews: Can [email protected], Copenhagen (25/01/2020) - dark amber with a off white head. Prominent Dr Pepper with notes of cherry, fruity and light spiced, cola notes, medium body, sweet syrupy notes, cherry accented into the finish. Does what it says on the tin! Fun stuff.

4/2/2020. Cask sample courtesy of danlo, cheers Ed! Pours clear dark golden amber with a bubbly white head. Aroma of fruit, malt, hops, biscuit and slight stewed veg. Moderate sweetness and medium slightly metallic bitterness. Moderate body, slight oily texture, soft carbonation.

Beer Names: Evil Twin NYC Millions of Peaches, Apricots and Almonds. Peaches, Apricots and Almonds for Me
Reviews: Can [email protected], Copenhagen (25/01/2020) - hazy golden orange with a white head. Tart fruity with prominent peach, notes of apricot chiming in, getting some of the nutty almond undertones coming through, yeasty touch, medium body, tart peachy lingering fruity close.

On tap at Nepenthe Brewing Co. in Baltimore, MD. 

Opaque brown-black with a thin khaki head and fair lacing.  

Aroma of roast coffee, dark chocolate, walnut, fig and dates. 

Taste of roasted malt, coffee, dark chocolate, fig and raisin. 

Medium body and medium carbonation.

Beer Names: Evil Twin I Talk More To The Coffee Cart Guy Than My Mom
Reviews: Can [email protected], Copenhagen (25/01/2020) - hazed yellow golden pour with a white head. Vibrant juicy fruity with notes of citrus fruit, some grapefruit and lemon, gooseberry, melon, light malty support, medium body, solid hoppy close.

Beer Names: Founders Barrel Aged CBS (Canadian Breakfast Stout)
Reviews: 750ml bottle from Windsor Hy-Vee, 2017 release, in a Sam Smith pint glass. Deep, rich, complex aromas of nougat, brown sugar, caramel, toffee, malted milk balls and medium-roast coffee with hints of wood smoke and green herbs. Pours inky black with two fingers of creamy chocolate head that laces gorgeously. Sweet and creamy on the entry with a distinctive maple character, turning malty and a bit fruity on the mid-palate with a long, sweet and roasty well-balanced finish, terminating with a flicker of heat as that 11.7% ABV hits bottom. Much more unique and less roast-focused than the original recipe. Ever so slightly sticky-sweet in the back of the throat. Completely satisfying and easy to drink for such a boozy full-bodied brew. Fantastic. Lives up to all the hype in spite of everything. Who doesn't love that? Founders certainly knows something about brewing beer. Thanks a million. Well done!

[email protected], Copenhagen (25/01/2020) - golden pour with a white head. Tart fruity with notes of watermelon prominence, veg and fruity notes, light salty, spritzy and effervescent, medium to light body, salty tart into the close.

Beer Names: Hoppin' Frog Barrel Aged DORIS The Destroyer
Reviews: A 22 fl. oz. bomber with no clear bottled on or best before date. Poured into a snifter glass. It was dark brown to black in colour with a very thin brown head that disappeared almost immediately and left only sparse lacing. Aromas of whiskey, roasty, chocolate, with hints of oak, molasses and vanilla. Tastes of sweet bourbon whiskey, roasty, chocolate, molasses, and oak, with notes of vanilla and caramel and maybe even some char. Medium to full bodied with soft carbonation. Overall, although perhaps a little sweet for me, the roast and chocolate did mostly balance it out for me, and it was still an enjoyable sipper.

355 ml can from Total Wine and More in Short Pump, Va  They need to keep the non-alcoholic beers in one area.  The ale poured a clear amber color with a white head and no lacing.  Awkward taste, with a malty aroma and grainy taste.

4/2/2020. Bottle sample courtesy of danlo, cheers Ed! Pours clear dark red / maroon with a small bubbly head. Aroma of mild blackcurrant, summer berries, light apple. Medium sweetness, minimal tartness. Moderate body, slight clammy texture, soft carbonation. Above average for this style of cider.
Found at El Tap in San Juan. Burgundy in color. Lots of cherry flavor. Intense sour.

Beer Names: Northern Monk Patrons Project 25.01 Everyday Abstract
Reviews: [email protected], Copenhagen (25/01/2020) - hazed golden pour with a white head. Fruity and malty, notes of pine needles, mango, orange, grass, soft sweet malty backing, light resinous bitter hoppy finish.

[email protected], Copenhagen (25/01/2020) (as "The Old Flax Store - Jack" appears to be same beer/style/abv) - pours golden orange with a white head. Juicy fruity with notes of grapefruit and peach, tangerine, soft malty backing, medium body, solid hoppy close. Tasty.

Beer Names: Other Half / Industrial Arts Nummy Nug Nug
Reviews: Pours a hazy, golden yellow, with mid-sized head. Aroma has some astringency, along with notes of tropical fruit and citrus. Flavor is citrus and tropical fruit, with some hop bitterness in the finish. Smooth and slightly sweet. Good stuff, this.

Beer Names: Odd Side Ales Sweet Potato Soufflé Rye Whiskey Barrel Aged Ale
Reviews:
Piana obfita i trwała. Barwa miedziana, zamglona. W aromacie gałka i cynamon przeplatają się z wanilią, koksem i melasą. W smaku słodkie, syropowe, przyprawowe, karmelowe, miodowe, wanilinowe, z rozgrzewającym finiszem. Goryczka nieduża, ziemisty finisz, gęste, ciężkie, nisko wysycone.

Taki trochę piwny kisiel z tego wyszedł, całkiem fajny jako deser...

Beer Names: Jolly Pumpkin / Jester King Citrus Commander
Reviews: [email protected], Copenhagen (23/01/2020) - hazy amber orange with a white head. Tart fruity with notes of citrus fruit, some lemon and orange notes, grapefruit, light to medium busy, tart lingering fruity close.

Acheté au IGA Benoit. La bière est rouge, littéralement. Elle produit une fine mousse blanche peux persistante. Au nez, la framboise domine largement. Au goût, on retrouve évidemment la framboise mais pas de façon sûre, plutôt de façon sucré. Sinon on retrouve également un goût un peu fumé. C’est très bon !! Facile d’approche et en même temps tellement savoureuse. Santé !

4/2/2020. Bottle sample courtesy of danlo, cheers Ed! Pours cloudy yellow gold with a small bubbly white head. Aroma of bourbon, semi-sweet apples, wood, citrus. Light sweetness and medium sour. Moderate body, slight oily texture, average carbonation. Dry, light tart, woody bourbon finish. Not particularly keen on the bourbon in this one.

Bottle at home in Hackney - picked up at Waitrose Canary Wharf. Pours clear, rich brown with a foamy, khaki head. Pleasant relaxed chocolate malts, soft roast, brown bread, very mellow earthy bitterness, nips of ripening berries. Light to medium bodied with fine carbonation. Pretty well balanced in the finish, more cocoa, mild roast, restrained bitterness, a whisper of coffee, only a suggestion of alcohol. It goes down very easily, it must be said. No issues here.
Clear red fruit juice color pour with a thin pink head. Sour taste with an intense raspberry flavor profile. Very nice sour.
De Labirratorium. En copa Teku. Programando GestorRed. Como una lager industrial bien hecha pero sin nada especialmente memorable. Pasa desapercibida

[email protected], Copenhagen (23/01/2020) - golden pour with a white head. Light tart fruity with notes of grapefruit and lemon, wheaty and floral and hoppy accents in play, minerals, light to medium body, fruity light hoppy finish.

On draught at the taproom during the "Streetside 3 Year Anniversary Bash!" on 09/28/2019. Cloudy bright reddish burnt sienna color with a medium thin frothy off-white head that diminishes gradually to a film. Short strings of lace. Aroma of tropical fruits, wheat and malt. Light-bodied with flavors of pineapple, wheat, passionfruit and biscuit malt. The finish is a fruit juice cocktail. Pretty good overall.

[email protected], Copenhagen (23/01/2020) - brown with a off white head. Dark toasted and sweet malty with notes of caramel and toffee, some dark dried fruit, wheaty and yeasty, medium body, hoppy wheaty lingering close.

[email protected], Copenhagen (23/01/2020) - hazed golden amber with a white head. Fruity and malty with lots of prominent herbal foliage, notes of spruce, pine, floral and herbal accents against a sweet malty backbone, more spruce and herbal floral piney notes into the close.

Very hazy orange colour with medium white head, aroma very citrusy, orange, orange peel, fresh, intensive. Taste rather bitter, slightly sour, low to medium sweet, lot of orange, orange peel, intensive citrus taste. Very very good

Beer Names: Wild Weather End of Level Boss
Reviews: [email protected], Copenhagen (23/01/2020) - hazed golden amber with a white head. Pretty sweet fruity with notes of lemon and grapefruit, straw, hay, grassy bitterness, medium body, sweet malty backbone, hoppy resinous bitter close.

Beer Names: Anarchy / Bad Seed Du Hast Hopf
Reviews: [email protected], Copenhagen (23/01/2020) - orange with a white head. Sweet fruity and wheaty, with notes of banana, some light malty and wheaty notes, medium body, accents of spices into the sweet lingering finish.

4/2/2020. Bottle sample courtesy of danlo, cheers Ed! Pours cloudy amber orange with a small bubbly white head. Aroma is funky, barnyard, cinnamon apple strudel, light biscuit and pithy citrus. Medium sweetness and slight tartness. Medium body, slight oily texture, average carbonatin.

[email protected], Copenhagen (23/01/2020) - golden orange with a white head. Sweet fruity with notes of satsuma with some grapefruit and peach, zesty fruity, light body, tangy fruity hoppy finish. So so.

Pours a cloudy, ruby red coloration with a medium, frothy head. Smells of tart rasperry and zesty lime, with a distinct acidity. Taste is a great balance of slightly sweet and quite tart raspberry and rather zesty lime, with a good lactic acidity and light salinity. Finishes with a medium tartness and some raspberry and lime lingering in the aftertaste. Smooth mouthfeel with a light/medium body and mesium carbonation.

A rather nice Gose that is recognizable as the style despite being flavored, with a good lactic acidity, subtle saltiness and very little sweetness coming through. The raspberry and lime work together rather well, forming a very enjoyable flavor profile. Very crisp and refreshing, makes for a great summer beer.
Delt med Rune på rom 410 Premier Inn Waterloo, Birmingham. Gusjegrågul. Høyt luftig skum som daler sakte. God appelsinaroma. Smaken fersken & plommer. Grei - men uvariert.

Beer Names: Weird Beard Little Things That Kill (Willamette, Columbus, Bravo, Ella)
Reviews: 4th February 2020Almost clear bright gold beer, small pale cream colour head. Palate is light and semi dry and has a good fine minerally biting crispness. Light lager malts, clean and with a pleasing mild sweetness. Crisp pine and crisp orange hops, touches of tangerine and grapefruit. Trace of citric peel. Crisp bright finish. Sometimes a later is the only beer that will do and this is a bloody good one.

Beer Names: Northern Monk Patrons Project 18.03 North Sea Sessions
Reviews: Can, 5%. Unclear yellow with small white head. Aroma is malt, fruit, hops, citrus, little tropical fruit and a little grapefruit. Flavour is malt, fruit, hops, citrus, little sweet, little grapefruit and a little bitter.

Can at the taproom during the "Streetside 3 Year Anniversary Bash!" on 09/28/2019. Hazy straw-gold color with a medium frothy white head that diminishes gradually to a film. Sticky strings of lace. Aroma of citrus, herbal hops, vanilla and malt. Medium body with flavors of pithy citrus, resiny hops, creamy vanilla and malt. The finish is mildly bitter hops up front with a vanilla aftertaste. Pretty good all around.

Sample at the taproom during the "Streetside 3 Year Anniversary Bash!" on 09/28/2019. Crystal clear pale orange color with a thin white head that dissipates quickly to a sparse outer ring. Spotty lace. Aroma of oak, tart fruit, yeast and malt. Light to medium body with flavors of gin, tart citrus, vinous oak and juniper.
